Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multiband, Ultrasensitive Terahertz Imaging Receivers Based on Quasi-Optical Balanced Hot-Electron Mixers

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore the realization and study the performance of a multiband imaging receiver system that potentially provides the highest available heterodyne detection sensitivity in the frequency range of 1-3 THz. The approach is to integrate a pair of identical superconducting hot-electron bolometers (HEBs) into a dual-polarization sinuous antenna to form a quasi-optical balanced mixer configuration. To further reduce the system noise, a superconducting microwave hybrid will be integrated for IF output. THz multi-band/reconfigurable frequency selective surfaces (FSSs) will also be explored to be employed in the receiver system. The research program consists of detailed design, simulation, development, and experimental demonstration of prototype receivers operating in the sub-millimeterwave through THz regimes.

The program's intellectual merit centers on the challenges and opportunities offered by integrating two HEBs into a sinuous antenna to realize a high performance receiver system suitable for multiband THz detection and imaging applications. The ultra-low system noise and multi-frequency operation are achieved by novel approaches of quasi-optical balanced mixer configuration, the integration of superconducting IF hybrids and the utilization of multiband/tunable THz FSSs. Advances in THz devices, circuits design and integration technology are expected. Insights gained may be transferrable to other THz detection and imaging technologies.

The broader impacts include both the creation of new scientific/engineering knowledge, as well as contributions to university education. In addition to the THz community, this work will benefit a wide range of science disciplines such as astronomy, atmospheric physics, chemical/biological sensing, and medical diagnostics. The graduate students in this program will be exposed to the full scope of the system design process, from devices to the system level. Undergraduates will be involved through summer and honors thesis research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, in collaboration with Notre Dame, seeks to investigate, develop, and demonstrate a quasi-optical, planar balanced hot-electron bolometer (HEB) mixer/receiver system with broad RF bandwidth for terahertz (THz) imaging applications. In order to achieve the goals of this research, the University of Virginia (UVa) team, in collaboration with the University of Notre Dame (UND) team, primarily performed research activities in three key areas: HEB device fabrication and integration and superconducting180 degree hybrids. UVA’s existing HEB fabrication capabilities have depended on a ‘Ti-line’ process to achieve the nano sized superconducting devices instead of a conventional Ebeam lithographic approach. The Ti-line approach uses conventional lithography along with the deposition of a thin Ti film on the sidewall of an organic polyimide step to ultimately realize a suspended Ti masking layer whose width is defined by the Ti thickness. This approach has worked well with Nb based diffusion-cooled HEB’s, but through this current NSF research we discovered that the Ti-line approach presented several drawbacks in realizing the phonon-cooled NbN based HEB devices needed for this study. NbN HEBs formed with this approach exhibited much higher device resistance than predicted by the original NbN sheet resistance and resistances that increased with time, even when a protective Ge passivation layer was incorporated. Our research revealed, quite surprisingly, that this resistance effect is due to our use of an extended oxygen plasma needed to form the organic step even though the NbN film is covered by a 15nm Au layer and 400nm of polyimide. Larger HEB devices could be successfully realized using a wet development of a step that avoided the oxygen plasma, but such large area devices were not suitable for the intended designs of this NSF project. Considerable effort was taken to realize a successful modified Ti-line fabrication process including the use of different RIE platters (conductive platters reduced the resistive effect, but greatly increased the micro-masking and hence decreased the yield), and the use of non-organic steps that could be fluorine formed in a much shorter amount of time (the final removal of such non-organic steps, to reveal the suspended Ti-line, proved problematic).

 

We ultimately turned to the development of a more conventional Ebeam fabrication process as our only path forward on this project.  However, the existing UVA Raith50 Ebeam tool is antiquated and during the remainder of the project we were confronted with several separate tool failure problems (UVA has spent over $100K in non NSF funds in an attempt to rectify this situation).  We have been able to demonstrate writeable 150nm Ebeam patterns with the tool that have allowed us to successfully fabricate test HEB elements. However, a substantial upgrade was required as the existing tool alignment capabilities proved inadequate to realize elements suitable for the desired mixer designs. A no-cost extension was granted and the tool upgraded with an ELPHY Quantum Lithography subsystem from RAITH, and a mixer mask (compatible with our new Ebeam process) set was designed and obtained. However, while we plan to continue this work, we unfortunately have run out of NSF project time.
